title: Why you should visit Sheffield and the Peak District, not Cornwall or Bath, this weekend
text:
Sheffield Town Hall (Picture: Getty) There is nowhere I have visited in the UK thatâ€™s friendlier than Sheffield. 
As you explore the streets and look around shops, you find yourself drawn into conversation.
Even when I walked into the Costa, it was so different from the vibe you get in London.
Forget Paris â€“ your next romantic weekend break is in Surrey Gone were the haggard, miserable faces staring down at their phones until they could rush out of the shop clutching a coffee cup â€“ instead, I got smiles, â€˜hiya loveâ€™ and friendly conversation.
It was quite a shock to the system â€“ but one I welcomed.
After a weekend spent driving through the Peak District and enjoying a drink while looking out over the city, I found myself returning home with the knowledge that a place existed where not only were the people actually cheerful â€“ but I could get a bacon sandwich for under Â£2. Result. 
The gin Bloom gin. Blooming lovely! #forum #gindrinking #bloomgin #sheffield #bar #mixology 
A post shared by Bonnie Pearce (@bonnie.pearce) on Feb 18, 2017 at 10:31am PST 
The Forum , located in the heart of Sheffield city centre, knows a thing or two about gin. 
If youâ€™re looking for a fresh take on this beverage, youâ€™ll find yourself spoilt for choice. 
The standard Hendricks and Bombay Sapphire options are available â€“ but those willing to step outside their comfort zone can go for the Manchester Raspberry Infused Gin, with almond, dandelion, burdock root and fresh raspberries. 
Nordes Galician Gin is infused with eucalyptus, hibiscus, liquorice and tea, Warner Edwards Victoriaâ€™s Rhubarb is blended with hand-pressed rhubarb juice, and Jinzu features cherry blossom and Japanese sake. 
There are 40 types to choose from , making the drinks menu a gin-loverâ€™s paradise. 
Raspberry infused gin at True North Brew Co (Photo: Imogen Groome) As if that wasnâ€™t enough, True North Brew Co, the people behind this gin heaven, run the Sheffield School of Gin , where students can learn about the history of gin, create their own blend using flavours of their choice and take the 50cl bottle home. 
The three-hour sessions are intimate â€“ no more than eight guests attend a single session, and youâ€™ll be paired with people who are similarly enthusiastic about gin. 
The food Pizza in the Slice Bar at Forum Sheffield (Photo: Gareth Arnold) The Slice Bar is open every day, from 4pm until late. 
Italian sourdough pizza is served by the slice â€“ with a growing range of craft beer available to go with it. 
If youâ€™re not sure which beer to go for, the staff are on hand to recommend which will go best with your pizza . 
For example, you may like to pair the Cheesy-E â€“ a classic Italian pizza â€“ with Five Points Pale, a light and fragrant vegan beer. 
Food at The Green Room, Sheffield (Photo: Imogen Groome) If you have a heavy night out in Sheffield, The Green Room is a good place to go for breakfast the next morning â€“ their bacon butty was under Â£2 and delivered promptly with a steaming mug of tea. 
Breakfast at the Leopold Hotel, Sheffield (Picture: Imogen Groome) For those who donâ€™t feel up to venturing out for their food, opt for a stay at the Leopold Hotel Sheffield , which offers an award-winning breakfast. 
The pubs and bars (Photo: Imogen Groome) Those looking for an extravagant drink will enjoy spending a few hours in Kettle Black , a bar which offers a range of elegant cocktails. 
The espresso is shaken with Ketel One vodka, Kahlua and sugar syrup, which is the option my friend went for. 
I chose the Lemon Meringue, which was mixed with Absolut Vanilla, Limoncello, fresh lemon juice, milk, cream and vanilla syrup. 
The Green Room, Sheffield (Photo: Imogen Groome) For a more laid-back vibe, The Green Room offers comfortable seating, decent background music and reasonably priced food. 
Itâ€™s somehow always open â€“ I rocked up at 8am one morning, then came back at 11pm, and it was still going. 
Whether you want to chill on a sofa in the morning with a cup of tea or head back for some drinks and live music in the evening, The Green Room is the place to be. 
The street art Another new piece from only a couple of days ago. A comic-inspired piece by @sill_art featuring one of their alien creatures. 
A post shared by Sheffield Street Art (@sheffieldstreetart) on Jul 31, 2013 at 10:18am PDT 
Everywhere you go in Sheffield, youâ€™ll find street art, graffiti and wall murals.
Absolutely brilliant collaboration between @xhastexo and @colorarti. Nice to see two of the best joining forces to produce a great piece of art. #sheffield #streetart #color #colorart #xhastexo #art #paint #spraypaint #graffiti 
A post shared by Sheffield Street Art (@sheffieldstreetart) on Apr 28, 2013 at 9:58am PDT 
Whether itâ€™s on the side of a pub, a derelict building or a shop shutter, artists will find a way to make their mark.
And after a 4 day paint, it's finished! After just in time to see the finishing touches added. Well done @faunagraphic #sheffield #streetart #art #faunagraphic #paint #spraypaint #harrybrearley #steel 
A post shared by Sheffield Street Art (@sheffieldstreetart) on May 3, 2013 at 10:50am PDT 
Kid Acne , Phlegm and Faunagraphic are just a few of the creative geniuses making waves in Sheffield.
The vegan quarter Sheffield has a vegan quarter (Picture: The Incredible Nutshell) Sheffield has a fairly new vegan quarter â€“ there are four vegan-run establishments within 10 minutesâ€™ walk of each other.
Burgerlolz is a 100% vegan eatery, offering â€˜kick-ass burgers with a twistâ€™. 
#veganrealness 
A post shared by Badgalruru (@rmjhh) on Feb 3, 2017 at 10:27am PST 
Vegans who want to get some food shopping done can visit The Incredible Nutshell â€“ Sheffieldâ€™s first and only 100% vegan grocery shop. 
Make No Bones is another place for vegans to get some food while theyâ€™re out and about.
The 100% vegan eatery offers a range of dishes for those who want a small and cosy venue to eat in.
Delish ðŸ¤— 
A post shared by Becka Brown (@plantbasedbecka) on Jan 20, 2017 at 7:04am PST 
The White Lion is a vegan-run pub, serving vegan real ale, cider and lager â€“ the perfect place to end your day in. 
White Lion, Heeley, Sheffield. Green tiled frontage and equally gorgeous inside too #pubcatchup #realalepubs 
A post shared by stymiesi (@stymiesi) on Oct 13, 2016 at 8:34am PDT 
The live music scene Mike Kerr and Ben Thatcher of Royal Blood perform at Sheffield Leadmill (Picture: WireImage/Getty) The Leadmill is a former flour mill thatâ€™s now a live music venue. 
It first opened its doors in 1980 and has seen performances from acts such as Pulp, Manic Street Preachers, Coldplay, Muse, The Stereophonics and The White Stripes.
The venue is so renowned that Franz Ferdinand once told Arcade Fire that playing the Leadmill was seen as a â€˜rite of passageâ€™.
If youâ€™re into a more alternative vibe, try out the Lughole â€“ the venue describes itself as â€˜run by the punks, for the punksâ€™.
The Peak District Some of the most stunning scenery in the UK (Picture: Getty) The Peak District is a picturesque area at the southern end of the Pennines, a mountain range in northern England.
Itâ€™s split into the Dark Peak, where youâ€™ll find moorland, and the White Peak, where the geology is mainly limestone.
(Picture: SWNS) Sheffield is an ideal place to go for a drive and explore the countryside.
Take a seat outside at The Norfolk Arms and enjoy a drink while you look out at the beautiful scenery and soak up the relaxed atmosphere.

Where to stay A deluxe king bedroom at the Leopold Hotel, Sheffield (Photo: Imogen Groome) I stayed at the Leopold Hotel , an elegant building in the heart of the city centre with rooms starting from Â£66 per night.
The hotel was originally converted from a boysâ€™ grammar school, and offers a range of artwork and unique architecture that serve as a reminder of its history.
My suite was spacious, with a sofa, Nespresso machine, deluxe king-size bed and bath â€“ along with a view onto the courtyard.
The breakfast room at the Leopold Hotel, Sheffield (Photo: Imogen Groome) There are many areas to relax, such as the breakfast room, afternoon tea area or the terrace, where you can spend an afternoon being served cocktails by expert mixologists.
How to get there For those travelling from London, itâ€™s worth considering taking a train.
The train from Kings Cross takes just two hours, with prices starting from Â£43.50 .
Making the journey by car, however, allows those who are up for a little adventure to go for a drive around the Peak District and Sheffieldâ€™s surrounding areas.
